awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Designing the Impact Studio -- Dynamic Visualizations in the Write4Change Networked Community
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging them in quantitative data analysis to support their own communication skills. The amount and variety of information generated and shared online requires young people to be adept at effectively producing, analyzing, assessing, using, visualizing, and circulating data. They must be data literate. This project investigates how adolescents develop data literacy by teaching young people to analyze their own online participation and to learn how to make their digital footprints have greater impact. Specifically, researchers will build and test a suite of visualization tools called the "Impact Studio" that will give students access to data about their online interactions. The "Impact Studio" will be developed and tested with students and educators who participate in a global online community called "Write4Change" (W4C). In this virtual community, youth and their teachers communicate online about issues of local and global concern -- for example, climate change, immigration, peace and conflict -- and explore how their own ideas and activities can contribute to solutions. Using the "Impact Studio," students will learn to deploy data visualizations as a means to test, revise, and more clearly express their concepts and proposals. Designing, developing, and testing digital tools that support students in becoming productive, civically engaged 21st century citizens, this project will contribute to scientific knowledge about how young people learn to strategically leverage data in order to produce, assess, and circulate information in a global arena.

As a design-based research study, the project develops and tests theories about how youth engage in data literacy practices to write for impact. Though the use of data is an essential part of analyzing, producing, and circulating information in STEM fields, this study broadens that focus to consider how the strategic use of data can inform digital writing. Across four iterative design phases that focus on building, testing, enhancing, and implementing the integrated visualization tools in the Impact Studio, the researchers will study 1) how the Impact Studio's visualized data displays influence student collaboration; 2) how students use data from the Impact Studio in communicating cross-culturally; and 3) how the capacity to create, critique, and manage multimodal representations allows students to leverage visualized data in their writing process (including the content of what they write, how they share and circulate their writing, and how they revise). The research team will first conduct design workshops and user testing on a prototype to refine the feature requirements for Version 1 of the Impact Studio. Researchers will then collect quantitative and qualitative data that track network activity and Impact Studio usage from W4C members (including interviews; participant observation; content analysis; temporal, frequency, citation, and interaction data from the network; surveys; digital competencies; skill inventories; and knowledge measures). After a period of data analysis, tool redesign, and user testing, the research team will undertake another period of data collection and analysis. This project will develop key principles about how to support students in generating and navigating vast amounts of data, critically interpreting and creating visual and textual representations of those data, and measuring the impact of their work on cross-cultural audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this project, Dr. Glynda Hull and members of her research team worked with stakeholders from multiple disciplines and institutions to reimagine online educational contexts as active and dialogic spaces for teaching and learning. Rising to calls for instructional resilience to cope with the effects of catastrophes such as wildfires and COVID-19, among others that shuttered university campuses and drove students to live at distances, Dr. Hull?s work began with an early effort to offer coursework online that departed from traditional models of learning asynchronously and independently through texts, to more flexible, creative, and engaging ways to participate. This work aimed to allow teaching and learning to continue to be delivered with the same standards and excellence as expected in traditional in-person classrooms in higher education, but also improved upon in-person learning by finding ways to exploit multiple modalities?print, but also video, image, sound, etc.?and to organize active ways for students to engage with course materials. As part of this work, Dr. Hull and colleagues designed, developed, and deployed a suite of digital tools that allow students to create, share, curate, and collaborate in order to make meaning and further their learning in their courses.

Using design-based research methods, each of the four tools developed as part of this work were iterated upon, taking into feedback from students and instructors using the tools. The most recent tool, which developed out of this grant, is the Impact Studio, a student facing learning analytics tool that provides students and teachers with various kinds of data about the participation and work of students in the course. The Impact Studio tracks and visualizes 16 activities within the host of four SuiteC tools and the Canvas Learning Management System (LMS) on which the course is hosted. Participation includes activities such as adding media to the course shared repository or ?Asset Library? (see Figure 1), liking and commenting on media ?assets? or resources uploaded by others, collaborating on multimedia Whiteboards, and remixing others? work to further one?s own learning. The Impact Studio (see Figure 2) features a unique ?Impact? metric, which communicates to users how their work is taken up and responded to by the community as well as how the nature of their work compares to the kinds of contributions made by other community members. Students can also use insights from this data to modify their participation and make decisions about the kinds of contributions they want to make to the learning community. Further, this tool allows students to find collaborators in the course and allows instructors to identify students who might be at risk of dropping out or falling behind. 

 

The Impact Studio initially started out as a tool that students had the option to use but were not directed to use as part of their coursework. However, our initial interviews with students indicated that the full potential of this tool was therefore not being realized. Thereafter, our team carried out a curricular update, introducing another pedagogical design cycle,  and integrated the tool more tightly into the course, aligning it with the course goals and content, which allowed us to intentionally leverage the full potential of what the tool made possible. Our interview data showed that, while some students were overwhelmed by the initial view of the large amounts of data presented to them, many were excited to see how their classmates were responding to and using their work and appreciated knowing that their participation in the course was not going unnoticed.  Further, students developed friendships with those who they discovered they had had many interactions with but were unaware of until they explored their ?Activity Network? (see Figure 3), a visualization of the connections between users in the course. Students also shared that the fact that they knew their work was being viewed and used as a learning resource motivated them to participate and share information in ways that would be useful to their peers.
